awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Topology of Functional Data on Random Metric Spaces, Graphs, and Graphons
awd_abstract_narration:
Extracting, modeling, conceptualizing, and visualizing information residing in complex datasets in actionable form are core themes in modern data analysis. This project will take up these challenges in the broad realm of functional data, as they permeate the sciences and practical applications.  The project will develop mathematical methods and computational tools that help us execute these tasks and establish a pipeline from functional data to actionable knowledge.  There is a vast landscape of potential uses of these methods. Examples include analyses of dynamical social networks, understanding variation in the spatial profile of gene expression to enable studies of associations with health and developmental outcomes, and exploratory studies that interrogate microbiome and metabolomic networks. 

The project will leverage techniques from topological data analysis (TDA) to further develop and extend persistent homology and integrate TDA with probabilistic methods. This will enable development of methods and tools for probing structural variation in functions defined on random domains. The project will develop topological methods, computational tools, and their foundations to summarize, analyze, and visualize functional data on random compact metric spaces, networks and graphons, and establish a pipeline from such data to actionable knowledge. The advances resulting from the project will open many new perspectives in practical applications and research in such disciplines as developmental and evolutionary biology, medicine, social sciences, and engineering. Though powered by state-of-the-art methods, the resulting tools will be simple to use so as to attain broad utility. To enhance this important aspect of the project, by way of interdisciplinary collaboration with domain scientists, the methods will be tested on case studies that involve analyses of plant shape, rock micro-structure, and human microbiome data. The methods and software tools resulting from this project will be documented and distributed online for use by the research community further broadening the impact on other disciplines. The project also will generate resources to support several outreach activities.

por.por_cntn:
This overall goal of this project was to study the persistent topology of functional metric measure spaces and graphons. Functional metric measure spaces are a natural model of data as it appears in a variery of scientific disciplines. There is a vast landscape of potential uses of the new methods, beyond those directly addressed in the project. Examples include analyses of dynamical social networks, quantification of variation in the spatial profile of gene expression and study of associations with developmental outcomes, exploratory studies that interrogate variation in metabolomic networks, and materials science.

 

Our key outcomes include:

 

O1: We developed a notion generalized persistence diagrams which is applicable to persistent modules defined on any locally finite poset [1] and studied multiparameter clustering induced by functional metric spaces [10]. 

O2: We studied variants of Gromov-Hausdorff and Gromov-Wasserstein distances between networks [11] and ultrametric spaces [2,3].

O3: We studied excisive and representable clustering methods in the contexts of directed graphs, networks and graphons [4,5,8].

O4: We introduced the Wasserstein transform/Gaussian Transform [6,7].

O5: We studied Frechet functions on metric measure spaces via topological methods [9].

O7: This grant provided training opportunities to several graduate students [12] and made several software packages publicly available [13].

 

References:

 

[1]  Kim, W. and  Memoli, F.. Generalized persistence diagrams for persistence modules over posets. Journal of Applied and Computational Topology volume 5,  pages 533?581 (2021).

[2] Memoli, F., Smith, Z. and Wan, Z., 2021. The Gromov-Hausdorff distance between ultrametric spaces: its structure and computation. arXiv preprint arXiv:2110.03136.

[3] Memoli, F.. and Wan, Z., 2019. On p-metric spaces and the p-Gromov-Hausdorff distance. arXiv preprint arXiv:https://arxiv.org/abs/1912.00564

[4] Carlsson, G., Memoli, F. and Segarra, S., 2021. Robust Hierarchical Clustering for Directed Networks: An Axiomatic Approach. SIAM Journal on Applied Algebra and Geometry, 5(4), pp.675-700.

[5] Memoli, F. and Pinto, G.V.F., 2020. Motivic clustering schemes for directed graphs. arXiv preprint arXiv:2001.00278.

[6] Memoli, F., Smith, Z. and Wan, Z., 2019, May. The wasserstein transform. In International Conference on Machine Learning (pp. 4496-4504). PMLR.

[7] Jin, K., Memoli, F. and Wan, Z., 2020. The Gaussian Transform. arXiv preprint arXiv:2006.11698.

[8] Lyu, H., Memoli, F. and Sivakoff, D., 2019. Sampling random graph homomorphisms and applications to network data analysis. arXiv preprint arXiv:1910.09483.

[9] Hang, H., Memoli, F. and Mio, W., 2019. A topological study of functional data and Frechet functions of metric measure spaces. Journal of Applied and Computational Topology, 3(4), pp.359-380.

[10]  Cai, C., Kim, W., Memoli, F. and Wang, Y., 2021. Elder-rule-staircodes for augmented metric spaces. SIAM Journal on Applied Algebra and Geometry, 5(3), pp.417-454.

[11] Chowdhury, S. and Memoli, F., 2019. The Gromov-Wasserstein distance between networks and stable network invariants. Information and Inference: A Journal of the IMA, 8(4), pp.757-787.

[12] Network data analsys group: https://ndag.github.io/People.html

[13] Network data analsys group GitHub: https://github.com/ndag/
